Cities looking to reform troubled police departments might take a look at Los Angeles.
The LAPD has come a long way in 20 years since the Rodney King beating, the '92 riots and the Rampart corruption scandal.
Court-ordered reforms have radically changed a department once widely seen as insular, bigoted and quick to use force.
NPR's Kirk Siegler has our report.
On the 11th floor of the LAPD's downtown high-rise, Chief Charlie Beck has been fielding a lot of calls since Ferguson, and he's concerned.
I don't want people to have to have their city go up in flames like Los Angeles did in 1992 to learn these lessons.
Beck's counterparts around the country are calling to find out how his department addressed what he now calls the ghosts of LAPD's past.
The lessons - and actual court-ordered reforms - began after Rodney King, and they didn't end until last year.
A federal judge finally lifted a consent decree the Department of Justice imposed in 2001 after another corruption scandal.
And out of all of this came an independent civilian oversight commission and a use of force investigation and discipline process.
It also marked a shift toward community-based policing.
We are where we are not because we are smarter or better than anybody else - just because we've been through so much.
Beck is popular.
He's a protege of former LAPD Chief Bill Bratton, who's now back at the NYPD.
